reviewText: Hardly the equal of his towering masterpieces with Janet Gaynor, Margaret Sullavan and Jean Arthur, MOONRISE is nonetheless an intriguing Borzage backwoods anomaly, rather a far cry from the bejeweled luxe glamour of Dietrich in DESIRE or Arthur in HISTORY IS MADE AT NIGHT. Reassuringly, in Borzage Love Conquers All, and MOONRISE once again validates that simple faith.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Moonrise is a dark mystery in the old film noir sense.  A little slow moving but with a surprising ending.  Lovely Linda Lombard (one of the dancers)is a friend, still beautiful and living in Florida.
Title: N/A

reviewText: RARE TO FIND FILM NOIR THAT IS A GEM BY THE GREAT SILENT FILM DIRECTOR FRANK BORGAZE..NOIR THEMES THAT ARE WELL PROJECTED AND DEVELOPED BY AN EXCELLENT DIALOGUE AND ACTORS.
summary: MOON RISES AND NOIR LIGHTS THE NIGHT
Title: N/A

reviewText: This could have been a really good film. It had very good film noir photography, the acting was excellent, the direction was good - but in the end the writing turned into nonsense, in the typical romantic "Hollywood" style. And the music, overwhelmiongly loud & out-of-place at the end, along with the writing turned a very realistic movie into Hollywood mush. Dane Clark played Danny, a character that was not easy to like & did a credible job.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Frank Borzage, a brilliant director of many 30's romances has his final hour with this wonderful film noir from 1948. And how lucky he was to have a gorgeous female lead, Gail Russell. She was the epitome of the starry eyed romantic lead.Beautifully photographed and well acted , this film is a lost gem to be savored by the film noir crowd.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A grim but effective crime melodrama, MOONRISE stars the pensive, expansive Clark as the son of a murderer who was hanged for his crimes. Clark is haunted by his father's past and tormented by his peers in a small southern town where his only friend is the incredibly beautiful Russell, (I thought Gail Russell had the  loveliest eyes of any actress in films!)  who's in love with him. A somewhat lethargic film, director Borzage nevertheless carefully develops his characters and fine performances are rendered by all. John L.Russell's photography is exceptional and that opening shot is astonishing!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just couldn't buy Dane Clark as the Virginian hillbilly. Clark was born in Brooklyn and educated at Cornell; I'd say miscast!Allyn Joslyn is convincing in a strong performance as the philosophical sheriff.Rex Ingram is solid and almost steals the film as the wise old Negro.Lloyd Bridges is excellent in a small role.However, the ending is just too lame and kills the movie for me with Grandma, played by Ethel Barrymore, convincing Clark to do the right thing. PLEASE.But, it is entertaining enough to warrant a look and the photography of John L Russell hits a home run.
Title: N/A
